Association: Genotype AC is associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype AA.
More Details: Reported as UGT1A6 variant 552A>C.

Association: Allele C is not associated with drug-resistant phenotype when treated with carbamazepine, phenytoin and valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele T.
Allele C is not associated with differences in antiepileptic drugs resistance risk when treated with carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin or valproic acid as compared to allele T.
More Details: Association was investigated for antiepileptic drugs as a group.

Association: Allele C is associated with increased glucuronidation of valproic acid in HEK 293 cells..
More Details: in vitro in HEK293 cells. Significance only as part of UGT1A6*2.

Association: CYP2C9 *1/*2 + *1/*3 are associated with decreased dose of valproic acid in people with Bipolar Disorder and Psychotic Disorders as compared to CYP2C9 *1/*1.
Genotypes AA + AG are associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Myelodysplastic Syndromes as compared to genotype GG.

Association: Allele A is not associated with differences in antiepileptic drugs resistance risk when treated with carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin or valproic acid as compared to allele G.
More Details: Association was investigated for antiepileptic drugs as a group.

Association: Allele A is associated with increased risk of Seizures when treated with carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin and valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele C.
More Details: This association was found in women but not in men.  The authors postulate that this is modulated through metabolism of estradiol.

Association: Genotype AG is associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype AA.
More Details: Reported as UGT1A6 variant 541A>G.

Association: Allele T is not associated with response to carbamazepine or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele C.
More Details: No significant association was found with this SNP and response to epilepsy drugs.

Association: Genotype GG is associated with drug-resistant phenotype when treated with carbamazepine, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype AA.
Allele C is not associated with differences in antiepileptic drugs resistance risk when treated with carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin or valproic acid as compared to allele T.
More Details: Association was investigated for antiepileptic drugs as a group.

Association: Genotypes AA + AC are associated with increased risk of Hyperammonemia when treated with antiepileptics and valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype CC.
Allele G is not associated with differences in antiepileptic drugs resistance risk when treated with carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin or valproic acid as compared to allele A.
More Details: Association was investigated for antiepileptic drugs as a group.

Association: Genotypes AA + AG are associated with decreased likelihood of Drug Toxicity when exposed to valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype GG.
More Details: Drug toxicity here refers to hepatic toxicity as assayed by serum levels of the enzyme gamma-glutamyltransferase (gamma-GT) (IU/L). The authors used NONEM to assess the probability of elevation of gamma-GT in epileptic patients administered valproic acid (VPA) using a PK-PD model. The dose of VPA as well as the presence of intellectual disability were significant co-variates in the model, which predicted increased likelihood of of elevated gamma-GT levels in epileptics administered VPA.

Association: Allele C is associated with increased response to carbamazepine, clobazam, ethosuximide, lamotrigine, levetiracetam, oxcarbazepine or valproic acid in children with Epilepsy as compared to allele T.
More Details: All patients included in this study were receiving antiepileptic treatment as either mono or polytherapy.
Molecules: carbamazepine; clobazam; ethosuximide; lamotrigine; levetiracetam; oxcarbazepine; valproic acid

Association: Genotype CC is associated with decreased response to lithium or valproic acid in people with Bipolar Disorder as compared to genotypes CT + TT.
Allele C is associated with increased glucuronidation of valproic acid.
More Details: in vitro in HEK293 cells. Significance only as part of UGT1A6*2.

Variant: CYP2C19 poor metabolizer and intermediate metabolizer genotypes
Association: CYP2C19 poor metabolizer and intermediate metabolizer genotypes is not associated with increased risk of Weight gain when treated with valproic acid in men with Epilepsy as compared to CYP2C19 normal metabolizer genotype.
More Details: Presence of a loss of function CYP2C19 allele was associated with greater risk of becoming overweight in females but not males. Patients took valproic acid for at least 6 months.

Association: Genotype AA is not associated with metabolism of valproic acid in children with Epilepsy as compared to genotype AC.
More Details: VPA plasma concentrations and VPA plasma concentrations adjusted by weight did not differ between the three genotypes.The authors classified the A>C variant as *3.

Association: Allele G is associated with drug-resistant phenotype when treated with carbamazepine, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele A.
Genotype AC is associated with decreased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype AA.
More Details: Variant described as GRIN2B -200T>G (rsID not reported).

Association: Genotype AA is not associated with response to lithium or valproic acid in people with Bipolar Disorder as compared to genotypes AG + GG.
Allele T is not associated with drug-resistant phenotype when treated with carbamazepine, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele C.

Genotype CT is not associated with increased response to carbamazepine, gabapentin, lamotrigine, oxcarbazepine, phenytoin, topiramate or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype CC.
More Details: The association was not significant after Bonferroni correction. However, when multiple variants were analyzed together a significant association was seen in logistic regression analysis of factors related to epilepsy treatment outcome; age, mesial temporal sclerosis vs unidentified, temporal lobe epilepsy, rs6883877, rs511310, and rs4828696 (p<0.0001).
Molecules: carbamazepine; gabapentin; lamotrigine; oxcarbazepine; phenytoin; topiramate; valproic acid

Association: Allele A is not associated with response to carbamazepine or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele G.
Biogeographical Groups: Multiple groups, 701 patients from Malaysia (Malay, Chinese or Indian), 803 patients from Hong Kong (Han Chinese).
More Details: No significant association was found with this SNP and response to epilepsy drugs after 1000 permutation testing for each marker or haplotype and Bonferroni correction.

More Details: The association was not significant after Bonferroni correction. However, when multiple variants were analyzed together a significant association was seen in logistic regression analysis of factors related to epilepsy treatment outcome; age, mesial temporal sclerosis vs unidentified, temporal lobe epilepsy, rs6883877, rs511310, and rs4828696 (p<0.0001).

More Details: as part of the UGT2B7*2 haplotype. All healthy volunteers were also UGT2B15*2 homozygotes and were co-administered lorazepam.

Association: Allele A is associated with increased AUC of valproic acid in healthy individuals no disease as compared to allele T.
More Details: as part of the UGT2B7*2 haplotype. All healthy volunteers were also UGT2B15*2 homozygotes and were co-administered lorazepam.

Association: Genotype CC is associated with decreased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotypes AA + AC.
More Details: and associated with significantly increased InCDR (serum concentration to dose ratio) compared to AA. Variant described as GRIN2B -200T>G (rsID not reported).

Association: Allele A is associated with increased response to lorazepam and valproic acid in healthy individuals as compared to allele T.
More Details: as part of the UGT2B7*2 haplotype. All healthy volunteers were also UGT2B15*2 homozygotes.

Association: Genotype CC is not associated with dose of valproic acid in children with Epilepsy.

Association: Allele C is associated with increased risk of Toxic liver disease when treated with valproic acid as compared to allele T.
More Details: 17 individuals with suspected valproic acid-induced hepatotoxicity were identified; 8 had substitutions in the POLG gene. Two of these individuals carried the rs2307441 T>C change (3428 A>G or E1143G).  When combining this allele with the rs3087374 A allele, the frequency of the alleles was greater in those with valproic acid-induced hepatotoxicity as compared to in ethnically matched population controls. Please note alleles have been complemented to the plus chromosomal strand.

Association: Genotype GG is associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotypes AA + AG.
More Details: and associated with significantly decreased InCDR (serum concentration to dose ratio) compared to AA. Reported as UGT1A6 variant 541A>G.

Association: Allele C is not associated with increased response to carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin and valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele T.
More Details:
This is a three allele SNP.  No association was found between any of the three alleles (C,T,A) and response to antiepileptic drugs.
Subjects on the different medications were pooled.

Association: HLA-B *15:02:01 is not associated with risk of Epidermal Necrolysis, Toxic and Stevens-Johnson Syndrome when treated with lamotrigine or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy.
More Details: Controls were patients tolerant to lamotrigine or valproic acid after taking them for at least 3 months without developing a skin rash.

More Details: The association was not significant after Bonferroni correction. However, when multiple variants were analyzed together a significant association was seen in logistic regression analysis of factors related to epilepsy treatment outcome; age, mesial temporal sclerosis vs unidentified, temporal lobe epilepsy, rs6883877, rs511310, and rs4828696 (p<0.0001).
Molecules: carbamazepine; gabapentin; lamotrigine; oxcarbazepine; phenytoin; topiramate; valproic acid

Association: Allele A is not associated with increased response to carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin and valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele G.
More Details: Subjects on the different medications were pooled.

Association: CYP2A6 *4A is associated with decreased metabolism of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to CYP2A6 *1A/*1A.
More Details: As measured by the steady state plasma concentration of valproic acid (standardized for weight and dose).

Association: Genotype GG is not associated with response to carbamazepine, gabapentin, lamotrigine, oxcarbazepine, phenytoin, topiramate or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype TT.
More Details: The association was not significant after Bonferroni correction.
Molecules: carbamazepine; gabapentin; lamotrigine; oxcarbazepine; phenytoin; topiramate; valproic acid

Genes: UGT1A10; UGT1A3; UGT1A4; UGT1A5; UGT1A6; UGT1A7; UGT1A8; UGT1A9
Association: Allele G is associated with increased concentrations of valproic acid in children with Epilepsy as compared to allele A.
More Details:
Subjects were pediatric patients (2 to 18), diagnosed with epilepsy and regularly receiving sustained-release tablets of valproic acid 2x day at least 30 days.
Steady-state trough blood samples were collected 2 h prior to the next dose and plasma concentrations of VPA were divided by total daily dose and body weight to obtain concentration to dose ratio (CDRV) and log-transformed to obtain a normal distribution of values (lnCDRV).
The authors tested 48 SNPs and found only this one to be significant (without multiple testing corrections).

Association: Genotype GG is associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotypes GT + TT.
More Details: and associated with significantly decreased InCDR (serum concentration to dose ratio) compared to TT. Reported as UGT1A6 variant 19T>G.

Association: Genotype AA is not associated with response to carbamazepine, gabapentin, lamotrigine, oxcarbazepine, phenytoin, topiramate or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype GG.
More Details: The association was not significant after Bonferroni correction.
Molecules: carbamazepine; gabapentin; lamotrigine; oxcarbazepine; phenytoin; topiramate; valproic acid

More Details: The association was not significant after Bonferroni correction.
Molecules: carbamazepine; gabapentin; lamotrigine; oxcarbazepine; phenytoin; topiramate; valproic acid

Association: Genotypes AG + GG is associated with increased Weight gain when treated with valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype AA.
More Details: Weight gain determined by change in body mass index (BMI) after 6 months of treatment. This association remained significant after Bonferroni correction, which was set at p < 0.0026. Please note alleles have been complemented to the plus chromosomal strand.

Association: Genotype GG is associated with increased concentrations of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype GT.
More Details: The GG genotype was associated with increased adj. serum concentration versus the GT genotype based on overall analysis (P < 0.00001). In subgroup of VPA monotherapy, adj. plasma VPA concentration was lower in TT genotype vs. GT (P < 0.00001) but was not significant in the combined therapy sub-group (P = 0.15).

Association: Allele C is not associated with response to valproic acid in people with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis as compared to allele A.
Allele A is not associated with response to carbamazepine or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele G.
More Details: No significant association was found with this SNP and response to epilepsy drugs.

Association: Genotypes AA + AG is associated with increased Weight gain when treated with valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype GG.
More Details: Weight gain determined by change in body mass index (BMI) after 6 months of treatment. This association remained significant after Bonferroni correction, which was set at p < 0.0026.

Association: Allele A is not associated with response to carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele G.
More Details: Of 325 patients with epilepsy, 94 were drug resistant and 231 were drug responsive.  Results from patients on the different drugs were pooled.  There were also 101 control subjects (no epilepsy).

Association: Allele A is not associated with response to valproic acid in people with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis as compared to allele G.
Genotype AC is not associated with response to carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy.
More Details: Of 325 patients with epilepsy, 94 were drug resistant and 231 were drug responsive.  Results from patients on the different drugs were pooled.  There were also 101 control subjects (no epilepsy).

Association: Genotype CC is associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotypes AA + AC.
More Details: and associated with significantly decreased InCDR (serum concentration to dose ratio) compared to AA. Reported as UGT1A6 variant 552A>C.

Association: Genotype GT is associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype TT.
More Details: Reported as UGT1A6 variant 19T>G.

Association: Allele A is associated with increased risk of Toxic liver disease when treated with valproic acid as compared to allele C.
More Details: 17 individuals with suspected valproic acid-induced hepatotoxicity were identified; 8 had substitutions in the POLG gene. Five of these individuals carried the rs3087374 C>A change (3708 G>T or Q1236H). When compared against ethnically matched population controls, the frequency of the A allele is significantly greater in patients with valproic acid-induced hepatotoxicity. Additionally, when combining this allele and the rs2307441 C allele, the p-value was even more significant. Please note alleles have been complemented to the plus chromosomal strand.

Association: Genotype TT is associated with increased concentrations of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype CC.
More Details: 4 studies evaluated the association between CC & TT and adj. serum concentration of VPA. In overall analysis of 4 studies found no association with genotype and adj. serum concentration (P = 0.35). In subgroup analysis, the TT genotype was not significantly associated with serum concentration versus CC genotype in monotherapy (P =0.71) but was associated with increased concentrations based on combination therapy data (P = 0.002). No sub-group anayses were done by age.

Association: Genotype AA is not associated with response to carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy.
More Details: Of 325 patients with epilepsy, 94 were drug resistant and 231 were drug responsive.  Results from patients on the different drugs were pooled.  There were also 101 control subjects (no epilepsy).

Association: Genotypes AG + GG is associated with increased Weight gain when treated with valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype AA.
More Details: Weight gain determined by change in body mass index (BMI) over 6 months of treatment. This association did not remain significant after Bonferroni correction, which was set at p < 0.0026.

Association: Allele G is not associated with response to carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele A.
More Details: Of 325 patients with epilepsy, 94 were drug resistant and 231 were drug responsive.  Results from patients on the different drugs were pooled.  There were also 101 control subjects (no epilepsy).

Association: Genotype CT is associated with increased concentrations of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype CC.
More Details: In overall analysis CT genotype was associated with increased serum concentration of valproic acid as compared with the CC genotype (P = 0.01) as well as in the sub-group analysis in combination therapy (P = 0.04). Hoqever, the CT genotype also did not significantly affect the adjusted serum concentration as compared with CC genotype based on monotherapy data (P = 0.10).

Association: Genotype AT is not associated with response to carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy.
More Details: Of 325 patients with epilepsy, 94 were drug resistant and 231 were drug responsive.  Results from patients on the different drugs were pooled.  There were also 101 control subjects (no epilepsy).

Association: Allele C is associated with increased response to carbamazepine, lamotrigine, phenytoin, primidone or valproic acid in children with Epilepsy as compared to allele T.
Molecules: carbamazepine; lamotrigine; phenytoin; primidone; valproic acid

Association: Allele C is associated with increased response to carbamazepine, lamotrigine, phenytoin, primidone or valproic acid in children with Epilepsy as compared to allele A.
Molecules: carbamazepine; lamotrigine; phenytoin; primidone; valproic acid

Association: Genotype GG is associated with increased concentrations of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype TT.
More Details: Five studies evaluated the association between genotypes and adjusted serum concentration of overall analysis (P = 0.01). In the monotherapy subgroup, adjusted plasma VPA concentration was significantly lower in the TT genotype (P = 0.0006) but not in combination therapy subgroup (P = 0.58).

Association: Allele C is associated with increased response to carbamazepine, lamotrigine, phenytoin, primidone or valproic acid in children with Epilepsy as compared to allele T.
Molecules: carbamazepine; lamotrigine; phenytoin; primidone; valproic acid

Association: Genotype TT is associated with concentrations of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype CC.
More Details: In two sub-group analyses the TT genotype was associated with dose adj. concentrations of valproic acid (VPA) but in opposite association with VPA concentration: 1) one study in combination therapy TT was associated with increased concentration vs. CC and 2) in two studies in a sub-group analysis of children on monotherapy the TT genotype was associated with decreased concentrations vs. the CC genotype. When evaluated overall there was no association.

Association: GSTM1 null is not associated with likelihood of Drug Toxicity when exposed to valproic acid in people with as compared to GSTM1 non-null.
More Details: Drug toxicity here refers to hepatic toxicity as assayed by serum levels of the enzyme gamma-glutamyltransferase (gamma-GT)  (IU/L). The authors used NONEM to assess the probability of elevation of gamma-GT in epileptic patients administered valproic acid (VPA).

Association: Genotypes AA + AC is associated with decreased bone density when treated with valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype CC.
More Details: Bone density in left femoral neck  and lumbar spine was lower in variant carriers vs homozygous non-carrier.

Association: Genotypes AA + AG is associated with increased resistance to valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype GG.
More Details: This was not significant after Bonferroni correction.

Association: Genotype CT is not associated with concentrations of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype CC.
More Details: The CT genotype was not associated with dose adj. concentrations of valproic acid (VPA) overall in 10 studies (P = 0.24). Sub-group analyses included monotherapy and combination therapy, nor by age.

Association: HLA-A *02:01 is associated with increased likelihood of Stevens-Johnson Syndrome when treated with carbamazepine or valproic acid in people with Drug Hypersensitivity, severe cutaneous adverse reactions and Epilepsy.
More Details: This allele was present in 3 of 5 cases alongside other HLA alleles. Case 1: HLA-A*02:01/*26:01, HLA-B*15:11/*51:01, HLA-C*03:04/*15:02; Case 3 : HLA-A*02:01/*02:01, HLA-B*35:01/*51:01, HLA-C*03:04/*14:02; Case 4 : HLA-A*02:01/*02:10, HLA-B*15:11/*40:06, HLA-C*03:04/*08:01. Authors state "Korean allele frequencies of the five cases' common alleles were 17.62% for -A*02:01".

Association: Genotype TT is not associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotypes CC + CT.
More Details: Variant described as UGT2B7 -161C>T (rsID not reported, from the UGT nomenclature website).

Association: UGT1A6 *1a is associated with metabolism of valproic acid in children with Epilepsy as compared to UGT1A6 *2a + *3a + *4a + *8.
More Details: The authors only genotyped three SNPs in the UGT1A6 gene: rs6759892 T>G rs2070959 A>G rs1105879 A>C The * alleles were classified as follows: *1 (TAA), *2 (GGC), *3 (GAA), *4 (GAC), *8 (TGC), *10 (GGA). The authors only provided the * and number but not letter. Here *1 corresponds to *1a, *2 corresponds to *2a, etc. The *10 that the authors provide corresponds most closely to *3b here. *1/*1 are wild-type, *1/*2, *1/*3, *1/*4, *1/*8 are single heterozygous, and *2/*2, *2/*4, or *2/*10 are double heterozygous. The authors evaluated differences in VPA dose, VPA concentration in plasma, and adjusted VPA concentration (concentration adjusted by weight) . No significant differences were found when comparing VPA plasma concentration between genotypes. Significant differences were found in adjusted VPA concentration when comparing between genotypes. Reported p-values are for those comparisons. After the initial comparisons were made for all patients, the same genotypes were compared in a subset of patients (n=34) ages 0-4. No corrections were done for multiple hypothesis testing.

Association: CYP2C9 *3 is not associated with clearance of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to CYP2C9 *1.
More Details: Clearance here refers to apparent oral clearance as assayed by serum concentration of valproic acid (VPA) (micrograms/ml). The authors used NONEM to assess serum concentration of VPA.

Association: Allele C is associated with decreased enzyme activity of CYP2C9 when assayed with valproic acid in human liver microsomes.
More Details: due to increased Km. Formation rates of 4-ene-VPA, 4-OH-VPA, and 5-OH-VPA were all reduced. This was also seen with expressed recombinant protein.

Association: Allele A is not associated with drug-resistant phenotype when treated with carbamazepine, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele G.
GSTT1 null is not associated with likelihood of Drug Toxicity when exposed to valproic acid in people with as compared to GSTT1 non-null.
More Details: Drug toxicity here refers to hepatic toxicity as assayed by serum levels of the enzyme gamma-glutamyltransferase (gamma-GT)  (IU/L). The authors used NONEM to assess the probability of elevation of gamma-GT in epileptic patients administered valproic acid (VPA).

Association: Allele T is associated with decreased enzyme activity of CYP2C9 when assayed with valproic acid in human liver microsomes.
More Details: due to reduced Vmax. Formation rates of 4-ene-VPA, 4-OH-VPA, and 5-OH-VPA were all reduced. This was also seen with expressed recombinant protein.

Association: CYP2C19 *1/*2 + *2/*2 are not associated with concentrations of valproic acid in people with Bipolar Disorder and Psychotic Disorders as compared to CYP2C19 *1/*1.
More Details: Dose-adjusted serum concentration and absolute serum concentration were not significant.

Association: Allele A is associated with resistance to carbamazepine, phenobarbital, phenytoin or valproic acid as compared to allele G.
More Details: p value was above significance level after correction for multiple testing.  Authors note that association was found at the allele level but not at the genotype level, and that this may be due to a low number of AA individuals.

Association: Genotype AC is associated with increased mean plasma drug concentrations of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype AA.
More Details: No CYP2C9*3 homozygotes were seen. Significance reported for one *3 allele vs no *3 alleles.

Association: CYP2C19 *1/*2 + *2/*2 are not associated with dose of valproic acid in people with Bipolar Disorder and Psychotic Disorders as compared to CYP2C19 *1/*1.
UGT1A6 *1a is associated with decreased dose of valproic acid in children with Epilepsy as compared to UGT1A6 *2a + *3a + *4a + *8.
More Details: The authors only genotyped three SNPs in the UGT1A6 gene: rs6759892 T>G rs2070959 A>G rs1105879 A>C The * alleles were classified as follows: *1 (TAA), *2 (GGC), *3 (GAA), *4 (GAC), *8 (TGC), *10 (GGA). The authors only provided the * and number but not letter. Here *1 corresponds to *1a, *2 corresponds to *2a, etc. The *10 that the authors provide corresponds most closely to *3b here. *1/*1 are wild-type, *1/*2, *1/*3, *1/*4, *1/*8 are single heterozygous, and *2/*2, *2/*4, or *2/*10 are double heterozygous. The authors evaluated differences in VPA dose, VPA concentration in plasma, and weight adjusted VPA concentration in plasma. Reported p-values are for those comparisons. After the initial comparisons were made for all patients, the same genotypes were compared in a subset of patients (n=34) ages 0-4. No corrections were done for multiple hypothesis testing.

Association: Genotype CC is not associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotypes CT + TT.
More Details: Variant described as UGT1A9 i399T>C (rsID not reported, UGT nomenclature website used).

Association: HLA-B *15:02:01 is not associated with risk of Stevens-Johnson Syndrome when treated with valproic acid in people with Epilepsy.
More Details: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome OR toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN). Carriers of the HLA-B*15:02 allele did NOT have a significantly greater risk of developing SJS/TEN, compared to those without the allele. This study was done in a case-control format, where 3 cases were compared against 15 controls; cases developed SJS/TEN on valproic acid, controls did not.  p < 0.01 was considered significant, after adjustment for multiple comparisons using Bonferroni's correction.

Association: Allele C is not associated with plasma concentration of the 4-ene-VPA metabolite of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele A.
Genotypes CC + CT is associated with increased concentrations of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype TT.
More Details: as measured by dose adjusted plasma VPA.

Association: Allele C is associated with increased response to carbamazepine, lamotrigine, phenytoin, primidone or valproic acid in children with Epilepsy as compared to allele T.
Molecules: carbamazepine; lamotrigine; phenytoin; primidone; valproic acid

Association: Allele A is not associated with drug-resistant phenotype when treated with carbamazepine, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele G.
Allele T is not associated with response to carbamazepine or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele C.
More Details: No significant association was found with this SNP and response to epilepsy drugs.

Association: CYP2C19 *17/*17 is not associated with concentrations of valproic acid in people with Bipolar Disorder and Psychotic Disorders as compared to CYP2C19 *1/*1.
More Details: Neither dose-adjusted serum concentrations nor absolute serum concentrations were significant.

Association: HLA-C *03:04:01:01 is associated with increased likelihood of Stevens-Johnson Syndrome when treated with carbamazepine or valproic acid in people with Drug Hypersensitivity, severe cutaneous adverse reactions and Epilepsy.
More Details: This allele was present in 3 of 5 cases alongside other HLA alleles. Case 1: HLA-A*02:01/*26:01, HLA-B*15:11/*51:01, HLA-C*03:04/*15:02; Case 3 : HLA-A*02:01/*02:01, HLA-B*35:01/*51:01, HLA-C*03:04/*14:02; Case 4 : HLA-A*02:01/*02:10, HLA-B*15:11/*40:06, HLA-C*03:04/*08:01. Authors state "Korean allele frequencies of the five cases' common alleles were 8.97% for -C*03:04".

Association: Allele T is not associated with response to carbamazepine or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele C.
Biogeographical Groups: Multiple groups, 701 patients from Malaysia (Malay, Chinese or Indian), 803 patients from Hong Kong (Han Chinese).
More Details: No significant association was found with this SNP and response to epilepsy drugs after 1000 permutation testing for each marker or haplotype and Bonferroni correction.

Association: CYP2C19 *2 + *3 are not associated with clearance of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to CYP2C19 *1.
More Details: Clearance here refers to apparent oral clearance as assayed by serum concentration of valproic acid (VPA) (micrograms/ml). The authors used NONEM to assess serum concentration of VPA.

Association: Allele T is not associated with response to carbamazepine or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele C.
Biogeographical Groups: Multiple groups, 701 patients from Malaysia (Malay, Chinese or Indian), 803 patients from Hong Kong (Han Chinese).
More Details: No significant association was found with this SNP and response to epilepsy drugs after 1000 permutation testing for each marker or haplotype and Bonferroni correction. Variant described as Thr1067Ala A>G therefore minor allele taken as G (here alleles are complemented for the plus chromosomal strand T>C).

Association: Allele T is associated with drug-resistant phenotype when treated with carbamazepine, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele C.
More Details:
However, The study reports that the genotype frequencies of 2677G>T ABCB1 polymorphism did not differ significantly in the drug-resistant versus the
drug-responsive epilepsy patients for GT genotype (P =0.71, OR = 1.14, 95% CI = 0.55 - 2.36), for TT genotype (P = 0.87, OR = 1.06, 95% CI = 0.49 - 2.26) and for AT genotype (P = 0.39, OR = 0.53, 95% CI = 0.13 - 2.24). (The alleles are given on the negative strand in the article.)

Association: Allele A is associated with increased response to carbamazepine, lamotrigine, phenytoin, primidone or valproic acid in children with Epilepsy as compared to allele G.
Molecules: carbamazepine; lamotrigine; phenytoin; primidone; valproic acid

Association: Genotype CC is not associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotypes CT + TT.
More Details: Variant reported as UGT2B7 802T>C (rsID not reported, obtained from the UGT nomenclature website).

Association: Genotype CC is associated with increased concentrations of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotype CT.
More Details: as measured by dose adjusted plasma VPA. Note: the mean age differed between CC and CT patient groups but was not significant (0.066) No TT homozygotes were observed.

Association: CYP2C19 *17/*17 is not associated with dose of valproic acid in people with Bipolar Disorder and Psychotic Disorders as compared to CYP2C19 *1/*1.
Genotype GG is not associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotypes AA + AG.
More Details: Variant described as UGT2B7 735A>G (rsID not reported, UGT nomenclature website used).

Association: Allele T is not associated with plasma concentration of the 4-ene-VPA metabolite of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele C.
Genotype TT is not associated with increased dose of valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to genotypes CC + CT.
More Details: Variant reported as FABP2 163G>A (rsID not reported).

Association: Allele G is associated with increased likelihood of prophylactic treatment response when treated with valproic acid in people with Bipolar Disorder as compared to allele C.
More Details: [[stat_test:  chi square]

Association: Allele A is associated with non-response when treated with carbamazepine, phenytoin or valproic acid in people with Epilepsy as compared to allele G.
More Details: Authors note that association was found at the allele level but not at the genotype level, and that this may be due to a low number of AA individuals.
